posts.name: Hitendra Bedacie
posts.cooked: My team has debated what to use as a vision coprocessor on our robot this year and are testing in the preseason, honestly im just looking for some guidance on how / why other teams  chose their setup for vision / object detection so i can figure out what would be best suited for our team, in doing so i have a couple of questions. On the localization side is the Limelight 4 worth it? how are its abilities, what about the Machine learning / object detection side?. We’ve also talked about using an Orange Pi with cameras using photon vision. Any teams who have used the NVIDIA Jetson how is it? Any controbutions to this discussion would be greatly appreciated, as right now im at crossroads trying to pick the direction i think we should venture in both vision and Object detection. Thank you for any assistance i greatly appreciate it

posts.name: Sam
posts.cooked: In terms of PV , I’d recommend checking out the quick start, Common Hardware Setups - PhotonVision Docs , if u haven’t already. LL can be used for both OD and localization, but I’d keep in mind that you need an additional purchase (a HAILO) for OD. If you go for a jetson, PV doesn’t officially support it so you’ll need some knowledge of the system and how to get it to work. It’s certainly doable, and teams have had success, but it’ll be a little less plug and play.

posts.name: Jade
posts.cooked:
If you’re just getting into vision for the first time I’d definitely recommend either following the quick start hardware guide for PhotonVision or utilizing an LL4. PhotonVision will be a lot cheaper to scale to a multiple camera and/or object detection setup but the LL4 is slightly less work to get started with, notably requiring a bit less wiring.

Sam948:

additional purchase (a HAILO) for OD

Slight correction, its not required CPU object detection just is very slow.

Sam948:

If you go for a jetson, PV doesn’t officially support it so you’ll need some knowledge of the system and how to get it to work. It’s certainly doable, and teams have had success, but it’ll be a little less plug and play.

I would not recommend going with a Jetson as your first choice. The Jetson is a very difficult platform to utilize.

posts.name: Jim Sokoloff
posts.cooked:
Anecdotal info: we tried vision for the first time in 2025. Photonvision, OrangePi, Arducam and while I wasn’t the programming mentor, I know they got it installed and working [uncalibrated] in a single session (of around 2 hours) and by the third session were servoing the bot towards a chosen tag.

The biggest hassle we had was the dumb wires on the Arducam and making a 3D printed case for it.

posts.name: Hitendra Bedacie
posts.cooked: Awesome, thank you for the feedback!, i had a feeling that jetson wouldnt be with PV , is there another software that goes with the jetson? or how would you get information from the jetson to use in robot logic? ( im very curious about the jetson)

We’ve used primarily PhotonVision on an OrangePi with arducams . While it worked, we had many issues with the setup. The camera wires kept breaking, and we had a struggle powering it until Redux released their Zinc-V . This offseason, we’ve been testing a limelight 4, and it has been amazing. It really just works and has worked flawlessly so far. I don’t think Limelight has been any better than our previous system, but it has been so much easier to implement and test. I highly recommend it for that reason, even though it is expensive

We’ve even had success detecting coral with color thresholding on the Limelight, even with a black-and-white camera, and we’re eagerly awaiting the color camera upgrade.

posts.name: Hitendra Bedacie
posts.cooked: This isnt our first year of using vision, we’ve used Limelights for localization but never started any object detection projects. i kinda wanted to survey everyone to see what reactions and feedback before i went to our coach with some suggestions. Thank you so much for your feedback and comments. any comment or suggestion means a lot

posts.name: Hitendra Bedacie
posts.cooked: Thats Awesome!, you’ve ran OD and Localization on the LL4s. Have you ever ran the Orange pi and the LL4 on the same robot at the same time, if so how did it go?
We did, and it worked, but I’d recommend against it. From a hardware perspective it was fine, but trying to cater the code to two different systems was a pain and slowed development time.

posts.name: Matthew L
posts.cooked:
We switched from Limelight to PhotonVision as Limelight 4s are too expensive (4*$449USD/$700CAD(tax included) which is not cheap). The team has had no problems, and PhotonVision was easy to set up and use, and we got auto-align working relatively quickly.

Yes, the camera wires are fragile, but we 3d printed cases like what @sokoloff suggested, and have had no camera wires break (so far). Fixing the camera wire is relatively easy, as well.

Jetson Nano is probably good, but it is not plug and play and requires you to do some stuff to get it to work, so we haven’t tried it

posts.name: Sam
posts.cooked: In regards to camera wires, there are a couple different options. There’s a jst to usb-c adapter that many teams have found success with, and if you choose to use a thriftycam, those have usb-c built in.

posts.name: tkchan
posts.cooked:
I think the most important question will be what will your “team” be most comfortable with - this would include your mentor’s technical expertises, your students and your budget.

LL will most likely be the most ‘off the shelf’ of an option as you can get but it will cost you more.

If “you” (by you I mean your mentors+students) are comfortable with dealing with linux/installations/etc, then PV will probably be a better (i.e. learning) route and cheaper. (2nd  selections would be on Camera types, co-processors type - RPi4/RPi5 vs OPi5/others and # of co-processors + # of cameras).

There’s no single ‘right’ answers.  At the end of the day, what works really well for one team might not work for yours.  Know “yourself” (mentors/students skill/tech level and budget).

user_custom_fields.user_field_4: think outside of the box from time to time

posts.custom_user_title: think outside of the box from time to time

posts.name: Paul Rensing
posts.cooked:
Do you have a reference for the adapter? I saw a post about a solder on board which then give USB-C, but that bypasses the JST; but maybe that is what you are thinking about?

For reference: Arducam USB C Conversion

posts.name: Sam
posts.cooked: Yup, that’s the device I’m referring to. Board is probably a better word than adapter, I just call it that since it adapts from the two ports.

posts.name: Hitendra Bedacie
posts.cooked: Another question for teams  who have experienced both, is it better to localize with limelight’s mt2, or using photon vision on a pi?
In terms of raw position data from the coprocesser, limelight’s mt2 is better in our experience. I’ve seen other teams do some processing on PV ’s results that get it to the same level.

posts.name: Andrew Todd
posts.cooked: We went with a similar solution and it worked great until we got hit so hard that our orangepi dislodged and smacked into a frame rail causing the micro SD slot to rip off of the PCB. Good times.

posts.name: Matthew L
posts.cooked: m.2 maybe? at least replacing an orange pi is cheaper than replacing a burnt out limelight (we managed to burn one and have the camera screws snap on the replacement)

Photonvision with the orange pi is an excellent choice. It requires more work in terms of wire management, cases, power, cameras etc. But it has two nice advantages. It’s 1/3 - 1/4 the price and you have flexibility on FOV.

The limelight is excellent as it’s turnkey, self contained, and has the benefit of a paid support apparatus. (Although the photonvision discord is phenomenal)

both are great choices.

posts.name: Andrew Todd
posts.cooked: Yep, except the orange pi 5 pro can’t boot from nvme. I learned that the hard way… bought a memory module for it and installed pv on that. Live and learn.
